summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan opposing Ghislaine Maxwell's request to use confidential criminal discovery materials in her unrelated civil cases. The government argues the protective order explicitly prohibits such use and that the materials pertain to an ongoing grand jury investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and possible co-conspirators.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330) who is seeking court permission to use confidential discovery materials from her criminal case in unrelated civil litigation.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. The government's letter is addressed to her.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased financier. The letter states the grand jury investigation is into his conduct and that of his possible co-conspirators.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The Acting U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York who respectfully submits the opposition letter.

connections.description: The government's letter references an ongoing grand jury investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and his possible co-conspirators, implicating Maxwell in that context.
Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal case, and Maxwell's defense counsel is making requests to her court.

events.title: Defense Letter Filed
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's legal team files a letter requesting permission to use criminal discovery materials in her civil cases.

events.title: Government Opposition Filed
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office files this letter opposing Maxwell's request to use discovery materials in civil litigation.

events.title: Government Seeks Modification of Protective Orders
events.description: The government applies ex parte and under seal to two courts to modify protective orders to permit compliance with grand jury subpoenas issued in the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Court-1 Grants Government Application
events.description: One court grants the government's application, allowing a sealed order to be provided to a subpoena recipient (the 'Recipient').

locations: Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The government has produced over 165,000 pages of discovery to Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team in her criminal case.
A grand jury investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and his possible co-conspirators remains active and ongoing.
The government issued grand jury subpoenas to a recipient ('the Recipient') and sought court modifications to protective orders in other proceedings to obtain compliance.

The government argues the protective order in Maxwell's criminal case explicitly states discovery materials shall be used 'solely for purposes of the defense of this criminal action, and not for any civil proceeding.'
Two other courts (referred to as Court-1 and Court-2) have ordered that filings related to the government's subpoena applications remain under seal due to the ongoing investigation.
